docs.lead_paragraph: ONE in four large employers plans to introduce a consumer-driven health plan in 2004, according to Forrester Research. These plans include employer-funded cash accounts, ranging from a few hundred to several thousand dollars, from which participants make withdrawals to pay for medical care. After depleting the account, the employee pays out of pocket until a deductible is reached. Here are some questions to consider in deciding if such a plan is right for you:

headline.main: Personal Business; Questions to Ask Before You Sign On

docs.abstract: Advice for employees on questions to ask before switching to consumer-driven health plan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tsuneharu Shigenobu and Sawako Kashitani, a professional couple in their 50's, are the embodiment of a Japanese dream: they have solid careers, respect each other as equals and even share the cooking. To top it off, their teenage children are now confidently moving into adulthood. Kyosuke, 19, is studying to become a patent clerk, and his 18-year-old sister, Natsuki, a high school junior, is planning to go to hotel school. Complaints from a couple like this might seem like ingratitude in much of the world. But as people whose careers reached their stride during Japan's financial bubble, they had expected more. Ms. Kashitani, an editor, agonizes that she may not have prepared their children for the difficulties ahead, while Mr. Shigenobu, a software engineer at Hitachi, wishes he could afford to switch to a less stressful second career.

headline.main: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Professionals; Wanting a New Job But Afraid of Quitting

docs.abstract: Fears for children's future are expressed by many Japanese, even economically secure professionals like Tsuneharu Shigenobu and Sawako Kashitani, who have two teenagers; photo (S)
